goals.question: What is the distribution of income in the dataset?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of income levels in the dataset and identify any outliers or patterns.

goals.question: What is the average income of the population?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the central tendency of income levels in the dataset and identify any differences between subgroups.

goals.question: What is the relationship between education level and income?
goals.visualization: Scatter plot of education level and income
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there is a correlation between education level and income, and if so, how strong it is.

goals.question: What is the distribution of income by gender?
goals.visualization: Box plot of income by gender
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any differences in income levels between genders and if so, how significant they are.

goals.question: What is the distribution of income by age group?
goals.visualization: Stacked bar chart of income by age group
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand if there are any differences in income levels between age groups and if so, how significant they are.

code:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['income'] = pd.to_numeric(data['income'], errors='coerce')
    plt.hist(data['income'], bins=20, color='green', edgecolor='black')
    plt.axvline(data['income'].median(), color='red', label='Median: {:.2f}'.format(data['income'].median()))
    plt.xlabel('Income')
    plt.ylabel('Frequency')
    plt.legend()
    plt.title('What is the distribution of income in the dataset?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    avg_income = data['income'].mean()
    plt.bar('Average Income', avg_income, color='green')
    plt.axhline(avg_income, color='red', linestyle='--', label=f'Average Income: {avg_income:.2f}')
    plt.legend()
    plt.title('What is the average income of the population?', wrap=True)
    return plt

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
    ax.scatter(data['education'], data['income'], alpha=0.5)
    ax.set_xlabel('Education Level')
    ax.set_ylabel('Income')
    ax.set_title('What is the relationship between education level and income?')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd
def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['income'] = pd.to_numeric(data['income'], errors='coerce')
    data = data.dropna(subset=['income', 'gender'])
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.boxplot([data[data['gender'] == 'Male']['income'], data[data['gender'] == 'Female']['income']])
    ax.set_xticklabels(['Male', 'Female'])
    plt.title('What is the distribution of income by gender?', wrap=True)
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    age_groups = ['18-24', '25-34', '35-44', '45-54', '55-64', '65+']
    income_groups = ['<50K', '50-100K', '>100K']
    income_by_age = data.groupby(['age', 'income'])['income'].count().unstack().fillna(0)
    income_by_age = income_by_age.reindex(age_groups)
    income_by_age = income_by_age[income_groups]
    income_by_age.plot(kind='bar', stacked=True)
    plt.title('What is the distribution of income by age group?', wrap=True)
    plt.legend(title='Income', loc='upper left')
    plt.xlabel('Age Group')
    plt.ylabel('Count')
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
